page.title: 01Chelsfield.
page.content: Chelsfield variously spelt in old writings Cheseld,Ciresfel,Chelsfeld and Chellesfield took its name from its cold and open situation,"Celd" in the Saxon meaning cold and "Feld" a plain or field. The parish of Chelsfield is quite large and in general lies on high land. It contains about 3378 acres of land ands about four and a half miles long from south to north but varies from east to west. Chelsfield, itself,has been split into two parts over the years by the making and use of the By-Pass that carries traffic to and from Sevenoaks and Orpington. The old village of Chelsfield still remains surrounded by countryside that consists mainly of farmland and woodland.The people of Chelfield can now reach London from either Chelsfield or Knockholt Station.
